title: John Akar
text:
John Joseph Akar (1927–1975) was a <a href="Sierra%20Leone">Sierra Leone</a>an <a href="entertainer">entertainer</a>, <a href="writer">writer</a>, and <a href="diplomat">diplomat</a>. He served as Sierra Leonean <a href="ambassador">ambassador</a> to the United States. Today, he is probably best known for composing the music of <a href="High%20We%20Exalt%20Thee%2C%20Realm%20of%20the%20Free">Sierra Leone's National Anthem</a>.
Early life.
Akar was born in the small town of <a href="Rotifunk">Rotifunk</a>, <a href="Moyamba%20District">Moyamba District</a> in the <a href="Southern%20Province%2C%20Sierra%20Leone">Southern Province</a> of <a href="Sierra%20Leone%20Colony%20and%20Protectorate">British Sierra Leone</a>, to an ethnic <a href="Sherbro%20people">Sherbro</a> mother and to a <a href="Lebanese%20people">Lebanese</a> father. Akar attended the E.U.B. primary school in Rotifunk, and proceeded to <a href="Albert%20Academy">Albert Academy</a> secondary school in <a href="Freetown">Freetown</a>. After he completed his secondary education, he moved to the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>.
Career.
In 1960, Akar became the first non-<a href="Sierra%20Leone%20Creole%20people">Creole</a> and the first Sherbro to be appointed Director of Broadcasting of the <a href="Sierra%20Leone%20Broadcasting%20Services">Sierra Leone Broadcasting Services</a> (SLBS).
In 1963, Akar founded the National Dance Troupe to encourage Sierra Leoneans to have pride in their cultural heritage. In 1964, he and the National Dance Troupe were invited to the United States to perform at <a href="1964%20New%20York%20World%27s%20Fair">New York World's Fair</a>. They were presented with a <a href="Commemorative%20plaque">plaque</a> won for giving the best performance of the fair. In late 1964, they performed at the art festival in <a href="London">London</a>. In 1965 they performed at the <a href="World%20Festival%20of%20Black%20Arts">Negro Arts Festival</a> in <a href="Dakar">Dakar</a>, <a href="Senegal">Senegal</a>. In 1966, they went on a four-month <a href="Concert%20tour">tour</a> of Europe, including performances in <a href="Germany">Germany</a>, <a href="Sweden">Sweden</a> and <a href="France">France</a>.
Akar was a repeat guest on the "<a href="Merv%20Griffin%20Show">Merv Griffin Show</a>" on television.
